Introduction:
Ys 1 and 2, the start of the epic Ys series.  I first played Ys 6 on the PS2.  That was a great Ys game, probably my second favourite (Oath in Felghana is mah fav), but just recently I realized they were on Steam and started beating them.  I recommend playing them in the order that they were created rather than in the order of the Ys timeline as everything will tie together better.  On that note, you aren't missing much if you don't play Ys 4 and 5 (I played both the NES and the PS2 versions of both).  If you do try them though, Ys 5 is more important as it explains a character in Ys 6.  Both Ys 1 and Ys 2 have the same mechanics and both have great storylines so this review treats them both the same.  Finally, if you're just in it for the storyline, no need to ramp up the difficulty, but if you're in it for the true Ys experience and all the achievements, start on the hardest difficulty... trust me :P  Onto the review.

IMPORTANT NOTE:
As this is an old game, it was designed to be run at 30 fps.  I somehow got all the way to the final boss at 120 fps on nightmare difficulty but after realizing the final boss was launching way more attacks at me than the youtube videos showed, some research revealed you need to lock the FPS at 30.  Right-click on the game in your library -> Launch Configuration Tool -> Enable V-Sync and Refresh Rate 30 Hz.

Review (spoiler free):
You can definitely tell these are old games.  Ys 1 was originally released in 1989 with the remakes coming after.  While the remake improved the visuals and was translated to English, the combat system is the original so try not to hold it against the game.  

Gameplay Mechanics:
Combat:
You need to walk into enemies to attack them... just with a slight twist (the game explains how it works).  While I'm not a fan of this and prefer the various attacks of the later titles, again... it's an old game so play it for the storyline.  Note: Ys 2 works the same as Ys 1, but also gives you different magics (combat and convenience).

Party:
Until you get to Ys 7, you go solo (no party).

Equipment/Inventory:
No crafting in this game.  You buy/find all of your items and gear.  On that note, Adol is not a thief... breaking into peoples' houses and rummaging through their drawers will not result in you acquiring pantsu (I tried).

Story:
Like all the classics, you are the hero.  Go save that princess.  Slay the boss man.  Ride/sail off into the sunset.  Great story and characters though.  Definitely required to understand the rest of the Ys series.

Final Score:
This game on its own (if you never played the other Ys games): 6/10.  I love the story, but gameplay is my #1.
As the start of the Ys series: 8/10

JRPG Bumper Cars.

This game is about some random character with barely an interesting back story who ends up on some island and for some reason decides to find the book of Ys because a fortune teller told him to. You should already be able to tell that the story itself probably isn't good. 

Generally games like this are fun to play. This one however; I'm afraid is the WORST jrpg game I've ever played. For starters, the combat consists of running into enemies by being a bit offset to their axis. meaning you must hit them by not running dierctly into them, but as if you're gonig to ram your shoulder into the enemies shoulder. Which would be fine if that was a normal, easy to do thing on a 2D game. It's not. You'll often find yourself accidently running straight on into someone, and then being bounced back. This barely damages the enemy plus you take damage. Absolutely ridiciulous. Moreover;  if you're just cruising around down and walk into someone, guess what, time to listen to what they have to say because that initiates conversation. Traditinoally you'd press a button to speak to someone, but not here. Bummer. Ok well that brings on the boss fights. Again - NOT FUN. Among the first 3 bosses, 2 of them go into "invulnerable" state where you cannot hurt them, instead you wait and/or run around like a chicken until you get the opportunity to - yes - bump into them off axis to do damage. The second boss in the game doesn't care about you playing the game. By that I mean, he'll bump into you an stun lock you, push you into a wall, and end you. So you must carefully run around in circles so he doesn't touch you. Also, the maximum level you can be in this game is level 10. Which takes about an hour to get. Enemies respawn the moment you move 10 steps into the other diection. Also the game fails to tell you that boss #3 can only be damaged by a certain weapon. So you can go into the battle, try hard, die even harder. I frequently had to consult some sort of guide because the game is just stupid. Not to mention that, in the very start of the game, if you don't talk to EVERY villager, you can't get the short sword which is required to kill things. I remember starting the game, an exiting the village an dying only to have to restart the whole game because the game doesn't have autosave function.

The games "dungeons" are basically mazes. And the best part is, there's no map! So you'll frequently find yourself going in circles. You could say "Oh I have good memory, I'll know where to go" but no... you will not. Because the game removes all light from the mazes. That's right, you'll be walkign around in the dark with light only being around your character. So if you have some paper, please be ready to draw a map yourself. Honestly, I did not have any fun playing this game at all. I'm so upset I bought it. It looked like a 2D zelda game. I may come back to this game just to get the achivements but as of right now, I can confidently say that, this game is noy enjoyable, especially with the bumper car based combat mechanics and the lack of any map/hints in the game. I can totally see this being a good game for like the 90's where you'd buy like 1 game a year an spend 1 year trying to figure out how to beat it. But if you value your time, play something else. I don't know how people gave this game a positive review at all.

40357222.review:
Ys I and II, both basically parts of a single story, are classic and influential Action RPGs, originally released at the end of the 80's. Their age is rather apparent, even in this remake, but they hold up pretty well and are still fun to play.

The gameplay is pretty fun, downright surprisingly so. The combat, with its lack of attack button and need to literally run into enemies, is actually quite engaging in its simplicity, helped by the fast pace and visual effects. It also works differently in each game, with YS II actually being easier. However, if you're not used to it, it can feel rather weird and possibly off-putting at first.

Ys II also adds a magic system, that enables you to fight enemies at range (actually necessary to defeat the bosses), find hidden passages, teleport to safe areas and even talk to monsters, which adds quite a bit to the game.

Exploration is a big part of the games and various areas are relatively big (but not overly so), with quite a number of hidden items to be found. However, particularly in Ys II, the dungeons tend to be maze-like, which isn't so bad when you're familiar with them, but can be pretty irritating at first. Also, it's not always clear what you're supposed to do, even when you have a certain objective, and backtracking is necessary multiple times (although teleport items and spells can alleviate that somewhat).

While the story is rather secondary to the gameplay, it's actually pretty well done. It's not amazing, of course, but really can keep you interested until the end. Some characters could have more presence, but most major ones are used well enough.

Chronicles+ is the definitive version of the games, combining both the latest Ys Chronicles with Ys Complete (a previous remake from the early 2000s) and even adding the original PC-88 soundtrack, which is quite a treat (especially if you like old video game music). You can mix-and-match between those, so you can have Chronicles' 16:9 resolution with Complete's character portraits and PC-88 music. Overall, this makes for a nice, well-rounded package.

But whatever you choose, the game looks and sounds great. The graphics aren't exactly modern, but still look very good, especially backgrounds, event CGs and character artwork. Although there's some noticeably pixelation in those, probably because they were originally drawn for lower resolutions.

Falcom is well-know for the great music in their games and the Ys soundtrack (particularly the second one) is among their best. There are no bad tracks, few decent, but many great ones, that stay with you long after you finished the games. And having all of them in three different versions may already be worth the price alone (and yes, it's possible to listen to them outside the games, they're all in .ogg format).

Ys Chronicles+ is a really nice package of two classics games, that started a great series, that never really lost their charm. Particularly if you like action RPGs and are fond of older games, it may very well up your alley.

39162845.review:
The Ys Series is probably the jewel in Falcom's crown, although I have to say I kind of prefer Brandish to what I've played so far of Ys. And at any rate, it's Falcom, so the crown itself is probably made of formica in the first place.

At least the first two games are sort of like if the Legend of Zelda games grew a functioning set of testicles and had a main character who was not sexually ambiguous enough that confused degenerates and women could project themselves onto him. And yet, I'm assuming the reason Ys is somewhat less well known is because Adol Christin is a ginger, and every time one looks into his empty eyes in cutscenes, it's like looking into the yawning chasm left when God stopped talking to us some time in the 1960s.

Falcom has survived as a smaller studio by putting weird gimmicks in their games that make you curious to see how they work. With Brandish, it was controlling a character who moved like a tank, and rotating the game world with him, rather than moving him through the world. They then usually undermine that gimmick in some way because it's difficult, time-consuming, and therefore expensive to develop a game around a highly unorthodox mechanic. 

With Ys, it's the 'bump' combat system, which has nothing to do with cocaine, despite these games coming out in the late 80s. The games lack any button for performing physical attacks, instead requiring that you bring your sprite into contact with enemy sprites with respect to the facing of their sprite. If you approach their sprite head-on, you both take damage. But if the contact occurs at an angle, only the enemy will be damaged. This is actually what turned me off of the Ys series when I first tried it on emulator years ago, and you'll basically know if you can accept or will enjoy it within the first few minutes of trying to play. 

How good you are at exploiting the bump system is essentially irrelevant in Ys 1, at least on the overworld where your hit points recover automatically while you stand still. Essentially, the only thing you need is the ability to survive a few hits from a monster, and you almost always can due to the massive ability boosts you get between levels in Ys 1. It provides quite a challenge in dungeons, until the developers got tired of having to do so much balancing and introduced the Heal Ring into the game. After you have that, you can also automatically recover hit points in dungeons, almost entirely eliminating the need to master the combat.

In Ys 2, the bump combat system is also rendered almost entirely irrelevant by fire magic, as well as an item which allows it to home in and another item which allows it to home in and split into multiple fireballs after hitting a monster. In relatively short order you'll be able to simply stand around and shoot fireballs to kill offscreen monsters. They do a great deal of damage to most monsters, and only about 3 are immune.

It may sound as though I dislike Ys 1 and 2, but that's really not the case. They feel like games released on a budget in the late 80s, because they are. And like they taught you in school, it's okay to be who you are, unless you're Lena Dunham. The main draw and the source of the Ys' games famous difficulty is the bosses, and those are mostly entertaining. Keeping in mind that I still encourage any player to put in the effort and git gud, the bosses in Ys 1 undeniably have some cheap tricks, although it's really only two.

The giant bat Vagullion does some damage that simply cannot be avoided depending on where he is on the screen, and the infamous Dark Fact fight has a strong element of randomness to it, with Dark Fact ponging around the final arena and destroying the floor wherever he's damaged. There are strategies which can increase your chances of winning, but you will need some luck.

The bosses in Ys 2 are another matter. I played both games on hard, and for the most part I found the Ys 2 bosses incredibly easy. I literally beat the boss Zava in one attempt and never used any healing items on any bosses. This is excepting the final boss Darm, who is a bit like a second attempt at a Dark Fact fight in that it's a supremely difficult battle with significantly less of an element of randomness. I did use a Roda Fruit to keep my shield up. I suppose it speaks volumes about the balancing of the fight that you receive the shield magic just before.

Ys 1 and Ys 2 share a plot, which is hackneyed 90s animu runoff about an ancient magic civilization, monsters, magic, and a dark lord. Although admittedly that's probably why I like it. A lot of girls seem attracted to a soulless ginger for some reason, but there are sexy nurses in both games to whom I was completely unable to administer a thermometer. Instead Adol is swooned over by a loli archetype and a princess archetype. This is why the Japanese can't have enough babies.

I did have a problem with the localization. The script has some 'hilarious' references to Harry Potter and The Room. I understand very well that there are things that don't translate into English, but that doesn't excuse references of this sort. I would rather see something essentially as intended and not understand it than see something completely different and completely out of place. Not everything is for everyone, and these games weren't made with Westerners in mind.

The games look excellent, and also allow for switching between three different music tracks. It occurred to me while playing these games that a lot of old FM synth music was made to sound like guitars and orchestras, and yet when I hear it orchestrated I always prefer the synthesized music. Possibly with the exception of Dragon Quest, because Sugiyama is a real composer. 

At any rate, if you can stand 90s anime garbage, the unusual combat system, and don't rage when faced with a challenge, you'll probably enjoy the first two Ys games. I played them simply because I'm exploring the series, but I did genuinely like them. Now moving on to Wanderers from Ys and its remake The Oath in Felghana. So if you have some time, offer up some prayers for me to little baby Jesus.

[h1]伊苏世界观的解构[/h1]
关于这一点，请允许我必须吐槽《伊苏O:起源》，这部简直是在用粗制滥造坑《伊苏1&2》的地位，作为一个官方前传，它不但没有填坑，反而挖了更多坑，许多设定和本传伊苏格格不入，除非看成同人游戏，我才能承认这部狗头续貂的渣作。
伊苏的世界观完全可以通过伊苏之书记叙的内容、位于天空伊苏国的遗迹，还有一些吉光片羽的资料推导出大致的过程来。就像《伊苏之书：法克特之章》所说的一样：“没有人知道这（恶魔消失）是为什么”，如果承认《伊苏起源》的设定，毫无疑问写了伊苏之书的托尔在一本正经地胡说八道。
伊苏背后有很多有趣的细节和设定可以挖掘。例如六神官的形象，显示出他们确实是六个经历了伊苏动荡和飞天的初代神官（[strike]老头老太[/strike]），杰诺库雷斯（就是伊苏1的第一个BOSS，法师一枚），在老版的伊苏里有个注解是“菲尼斯·托霸的救赎”。同理每个BOSS几乎都有类似的注解，而两个头的BOSS，确实分别对应了一对法克特兄弟。可见，在伊苏动荡的期间，六神官家族中有七个青年身上似乎确实发生了什么，但他们并非神官，记录了伊苏之书的本人。
根据我的推断，大致的流程应该是，库雷利亚被大量开采，滥用魔法，魔之根源污染了魔法之根源，诞生了大量的恶魔。伊苏全地陷入动荡，大部分人死去，但靠近萨尔门神殿却因为某些神力，例如护盾魔法，保留下来。六神官尽管封印了库雷利亚，但已经于事无补，只好龟缩在神殿里，甚至还失去了女神，不得不启动术式让伊苏的部分领土飞上高空。与此同时，民间发生了相应的自救活动，没有和六神官在一起的六神官末裔，分别参与了与魔物的战斗，但最终领导大家胜利击退达雷斯这样的领袖的，是一个拿着银剑的无名氏。消失的女神不是离弃了伊苏，而是深入了伊苏的中枢，以自己化身石像为代价封印了魔之根源。

38557174.review:
Jogo que marca o pontapé inicial naquela série que é excelente e amada (apesar de notavelmente desconhecida, quase underground).
Ys Chronicles é remake de Ys I e II, de mais de uma década - ou duas - atrás, com ligeiras alterações.
O forte dos jogos são seu gráfico otimizado, não sendo feito para ser 4K ultra HD, 999 FPS, mas sim, bonito em seu nicho, cumprindo seu papel de maneira perfeita.
O ponto alto do jogo:
História: Ao contrário de muitos jogos de rpg, sejam action rpgs ou rpgs puros, não exige dezenas de horas de jogo para alcançar o final. E ainda não apresenta história corrida, apressada.
Músicas: A trilha sonora é memorável, vibrante, climática. Dependendo do jogador, podem considerar a música ainda melhor que a história.

Pontos ruins:
Dificuldade: O jogo não possui tutoriais ou algo do gênero. No máximo, uma informação simples e aproveite bem ela. Exige grinding na maioria das vezes, seja para XP ou para coleta de gold. A exploração pode cansar os mais incaltos, já que exige idas e vindas e certas localidades confundem os mais desavisados. No entanto, não é um jogo difícil para os familiarizados com jogos old-school.
Tempo de jogo: Apesar da história não ser corrida, o jogo pode ser terminado com muita rapidez (talvez 10 horas num first-run, caindo pra 2 ou 3 horas, quando já habituado, sendo 10 pro I e 10 pro II, no caso). Apesar disto, o fator replay (com dificuldades extras e um modo Time Attack/Boss Rush) compensa pela campanha principal curta.

Я не знаю, что курили авторы, убрав или не введя вообще возможность пропуска диалогов.  伊苏一二里还有一点我觉得好的是身上有交互物品，你得在人面前主动使用才能触发对话，比如蕾雅的诗，到了后面几代只要你身上有东西就能自动触发了。虽然是方便人的设计，但我想说NPC们你们都是透视眼吗！！！这么方便的能力也分我一份啊！！！

38008129.review:
[i][Review updated on 02/10/18 after completing Ys II][/i]

For a change of pace, I wanted to play a Japanese role-playing game (JRPG) series, and I stumbled across Nihon Falcom's [i]Ys[/i]. But playing the series from the beginning would require booting up a game that was originally released 30 years ago in 1987. The story begins with our hero washing up on a foreign shore and questing and fighting his way through the land of Esteria. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Both Ys I and II employ an arcade-style "bump attack" system where our hero runs into enemies to damage them. The game is played using keyboard commands and arrow keys. The first few battles create the impression that the game is going to be a breeze, but once you enter the underground dungeon areas - where health points no longer replenish when standing still - the difficulty level goes up a notch. And once you confront the first boss - and each subsequent boss - you start to wonder if you made a mistake trying to play this game. The boss fights are quite challenging and, with one exception, I found myself looking at online walkthroughs for tips on how to defeat each one. Ultimately, defeating the bosses and the game are a rewarding experience. Completing some of the quests is equally challenging and also required occasionally dipping into online walkthroughs to make sure I was on the right track.

[b]Characters/Customization[/b]
Outside their role in the story, the characters in the game are not particularly memorable. Our hero does obtain equipment upgrades along the way, but that and leveling (both of which increase damage output, defense, and health points) are about the extent of character growth in the game.

[b]Story/Atmosphere[/b]
The story, set in the land of Esteria, starts when our hero Adol Christin washes up on the shore after a storm. He then embarks on an adventure to discover the mystery behind the lost kingdom of Ys and to defeat the dark forces that have started to spread in Esteria. By modern standards, the story is stereotypical for the fantasy genre as are the various types of zones (e.g. hostile wilderness, quaint towns, dark caverns, evil towers). Combined with late 80's graphics, this should have had disaster written all over it, but the game has an undeniable charm that drives a sense of nostalgia and longing for those simpler (PC gaming) days. It is that charm that makes it possible to enjoy the game from beginning to end.

[b]Graphics/Sound[/b]
Knowing that the graphics are from the late 80's helps temper expectations. Perhaps more important are colors and lighting effects that give the game a distinct feel. The music has been cited by others as a major plus in the game, and while I agree that the heavy metal instrumentals are pretty awesome and high quality, they do seem a little out of place in the fantasy setting, but I suppose they are a reasonable given the arcade-style gameplay. My favorite musical track is actually the harmonica number played by the traveling minstrel during the opening cinematic.

For the most part the Steam version of the game works without issues. Some of the bosses, however, were bordering on impossible with my initial settings. Two tips that helped me overcome the final boss included (a) unticking the "Full Screen" option in the [b]Launch Configuration Tool[/b] and (b) limiting the "Refresh Rate" to 60 Hz. I was still able to finish with 1920 x 1080 resolution (and effectively a full screen display).

[b]Replay Value:[/b] None. The first game took me roughly 10 hours to complete. The second game took me longer (15 hours), possibly due to reloads against some of the tougher bosses.

[b]Note on [i]Ys II[/i][/b]
The second part, [i]Ys II[/i], is basically "more of the same". As far as I can tell, both games were developed at the same time and, at some point, split into two acts, two games.

[b]Overall Score:[/b] 6/10

[i]Played in 2017-2018.[/i]

36686296.review:
Ys is a series that I have only recently gotten into, with Ys I & II Chronicles being my first ever experience with the series. 

If you are familiar with the later games in the series, you know that they are fast paced action games with amazing boss battles and soundtracks. While Ys 1 & 2 do have a lot of those things (namely the soundtrack and boss battles being awesome) there are a few key differences that can make or break the experience for you.

First off, the localization is a lot of fun in Chronicles. The standout for me is Ys 2 in this collection especially. There is a gift giving system that, despite there being few real rewards from it, is a treat if you appreciate witty dialogue. Rather this means apologizing to someone becaused you "Lit their ass on fire" by giving them a few more gifts than normal, or wooing a woman right in front of her husband, there is a lot of fun to be had with that.

As far as the soundtrack goes, Chronicles+ gives you a lot of customization. You can choose from 3 different versions of the soundtrack from the Turbo Grafx, the PSP Complete collection, or the more modern Chronicles mix. Personally I prefer either the Complete or Chronicles soundtracks, but thanks to being able to switch the soundtrack on the fly you can listen to each BGM all 3 ways and see which one you prefer. 

The largest barrier to being able to enjoy the Chronicles+ collection is the combat system. Unlike later Ys which use a much more traditional Zelda style battle system, Ys 1 & 2 use the Bump System. Essentially, you just ram your character into enemies to hurt them. The key is to bump into them slightly off center to avoid being damaged yourself, but the hit detection isn't always what you would think it should be. 
Personally, the system didn't detract from my experience. However, these were my first Ys games. If you are a a fan of the newer Ys games hoping to play the original games that started it all, you might not be able to look past the strange battle system. 

The bosses in the Ys series continue to impress me as I make my way further down the rabbit hole, and 1 & 2 have some great ones. Ys 1 has a clear disadvatage here, with some bosses that can be outright frustrating for all the wrong reasons. There are two bosses that I can recall that felt cheap and relied far too much on luck than skill. One of these was the final boss, which doesn't make for a very convincing showdown (I should mention that I only played through Ys 1 and 2 on the Nightmare difficulty setting, so these problems may go away on lower difficulties). Even with some stumbles, for the most part BOTH games have incredibly well designed bosses, both graphically and mechanically.

When you get right down to it, I do recommend Chronicles+. It's not perfect, but it's a memorable experience with some truly astounding sound direction and epic boss battles. If you are a newcomer to the series, I recommend starting here. If you start with something like Ys: Oath in Felghanna, you might not be able to enjoy these as much thanks to the difference in gameplay. Veterans of the series should only come back if they think they can handle gameplay that feels like a decided step down. Even so, there are a lot of great moments to be had here as long as you don't expect the best in the series.

36259320.review:
This review is being written purely for Ys I. If I go through Ys II I'll amend it as needed.

This game isn't necessarily a bad game. I feel like it has a lot of merits to it for a short (6-7 hours) RPG, but it just doesn't come together very well. 

[b]Things I liked:[/b]
*The combat is quirky and I can see people not liking it, but I felt it was refreshingly fast and unique when compared to your average turn-based slog.  I would have liked a bit more variance though, such as combat related items, magic, or similar secondary attacks.

*The game is cleanly made. While the cutscenes are dated, the graphics overall are quite nice, if simple. 

*The items collecting. While it's not everyone's cup of tea, I'm a huge sucker for games with lots of items to collect. I'm reminded of things such as La Mulana and The Legend of Zelda: LTTP. 

*The soundtrack is honestly kickass. Not much needs to be said about it beyond that.

While these things are nice, there are a lot of problems I have with the game that these just can't redeem.

[b]Things I disliked:[/b]
*The story is not exactly thrilling. It's incredibly basic and generic, and while there's a few interesting bits here and there, they're too sparsely scattered across what is ultimately a painfully boring plot of a generic hero collecting every ancient artifact the world over in a single evening and wooing the girl(s). Oh, and saving the world from a generic fantasy apocalypse. Woo.

*The art, while high quality, is just dull. I'm instantly reminded of decades of unmodified RPGmaker graphics, and as a result, immersing myself in the world is difficult. Between this and the plot, the game comes off as so standard that I'm not sure what to really get excited for.

*The experience mechanics. The levels cap out at 10 halfway through the game, and are practically hard-caps on your progression. The standard enemies either kill you in a few hits, or go down pathetically easy. I feel like the game would be better without the levels entirely, instead substituting in something like slightly more granular equipment.

*The bosses. While they're a good challenge and I don't think they're unfairly difficult, they are boring. I'm pretty sure every boss (except the final boss) has a single attack. Some bosses lack actual attacks entirely, and just rely on bumping into you to deal damage. I feel like a little more variance would've gone a huge way in making the bosses feel more exciting and enjoyable.

Overall, while it's certainly not bad, I can't recommend it. If you don't mind generic games or it goes on sale for cheap, it might be worth it. Otherwise, there's definitely better out there for cheaper.

35202916.review:
THE GOOD
-Combat
You attack enemies by walking into them. Sounds dumb doesn’t it. Why don’t you try watching some gameplay footage of it? Still looks pretty stupid huh? You’re probably thinking how can such a combat system be fun? Well, it is. Ys I and II’s combat system is simple yet fun. It’s one of those things which sounds dumb on paper but is really good in practice. All you need to think of in combat (outside of boss battles) is walk into enemies but don’t collide with them in the centre. For anybody who studies game design, often you would want to aim for the lowest amount of complexity but a high amount of depth, which is what Ys I and II has done with their combat system. It lacks complexity but has a large amount of depth, in other words it is easy to learn yet hard to master, which is great. Such a combat system may sound really boring and easy, but adding in the speed at which Adol, the main character, moves, this creates a very fast pace combat system that is thrilling no matter how many times I experience it.
P.s. If u think the enemy movements in Ys I is too easy, Ys II improves on them by allowing the enemies to move diagonally make the combat tougher

-Boss Battles
All boss battles are unique, no two are the same. Some of these boss fights are really tough and that’s just how I like it. Of course, you could just grind to the point where your level is so high that the boss isn’t even a threat, but where’s the fun in that? I often find myself trying and failing time and time again to beat the same boss. However, each time I get more familiar with the boss’s attack patterns and then eventually I win and that sense of satisfaction I get is just exhilarating.
P.s. I do see some people complaining about how unfair the Vagullion (the bat) boss fight was but I didn’t have too much trouble dealing him so I guess to each his own.

-Story
It’s a typical boy saves the world anime fantasy story with a small amount of romance sprinkled in. It’s simple, nothing really special about it. However, simple is often best when it comes to stories in video games. Video games aren’t a very good storytelling medium. The story often just serves as a motivation for the player to push on or give the player some context and meaning as to what they are doing in the game. Thus, a simple story in a video game not only serves it’s purpose, it also makes it easy for the player to follow along and not get lost in a convoluted mess which is Final Fantasy.

THE BAD
-Backtracking
This problem isn’t really apparent in Ys I as Ys I’s world is pretty small, and the story is considerably shorter than Ys II. However, in Ys II, there are a lot of times in the game where the main story requires you to backtrack. Of course, to makes things easier, you are given Warp Magic pretty early in the game which allows you to warp to any town you have visited. But the problem is that the map of Ys II is non-linear. A lot of areas are maze-like and it’s easy to get lost or struggle to find a door you stumbled upon previously but couldn’t unlock because you didn’t have the key yet. I get that backtracking is quite normal in RPGs and honestly I’m not really against it. What I am against though, is the maze-like areas which require backtracking. It gets annoying pretty quickly and at times feels like a lazy way to lengthen the game unnecessarily. 

OVERALL
All in all, this is the first (and second) Ys game(s) I've played and I had a lot of fun. I'm a huge fan of this franchise now and can't wait to play another Ys game.

33531712.review:
Ys I is great. It's a tight, short game with simple mechanics. You just 'bump' into enemeis to attack, but never straight on, so there is finesse to it. Running across the fields, mowing enemies and running into them as they all blow up into bits of bones flesh and gore is so satisfying. Bosses are a really good challenge, and torwards the end they all become consistently high quality and are rewarding to defeat. The music is fantastic as well.

Ys II is almost good. It brings the same gameplay to the table, adding in magic and mapping items to a key to heal on the fly. The magic is good- light to brighten up surroundings and reveal hidden enemies, fire as a standard chargeable projectile, and my favorite- turning into a creature to converse with enemies, with each you encounter having specific and unique dialogues. They talk a lot about shifts and something of urban legends about the protagonist, or just funny things. It's great. 

However, Ys II falters in a few ways. The game is just SO labrynthine. This wasn't a problem in I- there was one cave area which was annoying but it doesn't really even touch how bad it gets in II. Places are just so large and complex, which would be okay, but often times paths look very similiar and there aren't enough landmarks or distinctive areas to really know where the hell you are a lot of the time. And lots of dead ends too. Being an ARPG this isn't as bad as it could be, but enemies will still respawn and there's just no map function. Worse yet, combined with this you can miss important items and will have to backtrack again on top of already required backtracking. It's annoying, especially when you've finally reached a boss but it turns out there's a sword that will let you do more than mere chip damage to them. I couldn't finish the game, I reached about 3/4ths through it when I decided I had enough. It's a shame because there's a lot of good qualities but the map design makes it a tedious game.

The end result is that I is fantastic and II is worth a shot but not as good. Regardless, they both have good qualities. Not enough can be said of the good music, and the core gameplay is still good in both- just bogged down in II by other things.

33291515.review:
Classic, old school, and a challenge. 

Ys I & II Chronicles is a good remake spin on a old school way of gaming. This is a fun RPG set that's fast paced, fun, and has outstanding music!  At the time of this review i've finished Ys I, and am currently working on Ys 2, but i've seen enough to work this review.   The games are well developed and actually well balanced in several aspects. Game makes you feel powerful and gives you lots of levels for grinding, but does a good job keeping you down until you get your next set of equipment. The challenges of this game are actually very reminiscent of Zelda 1 in the aspect of exploration and  discovery. The game will give you clues, but will not hold your hand. If you don't pay attention, you can get lost on what to do. Details are in the text, and the rest is up to you to discover how to bridge the next piece of the story. This is a good reminder of a time before the internet and walkthroughs, and how you needed to be in charge of the game and make your way through on your own.  I won't spoil any story points, but I can say that it can be REALLY challenging at times.

Music is outstanding, as I mentioned with a lot of great multi-instrumental sounds based on where you are, and it never gets old. These are the kind of tunes for your gaming music playlist.   

Sound is pretty typical, no voice acting, and without music, it's just a bunch of floor tapping and sword swiping, so nothing too great there. 

Controls are okay.  The combat is a bumper system, which is another old school RPG method. Kind of interesting to play it in a modern time, but it's simple. In Ys II you get magic, and casting is just A, so that's about the only innovative thing. To talk to people, you just bump into them as well.

Overall, Ys Chronicles is a great game. It's not perfect, and can be frustrating at times too, but a great game because it's classic, and not catering to the player. It welcomes the player to think and figure out the story. They give you the string, and you follow it.  This is a perfect game for those who loved Zelda 1, and other old school style RPG's!   

EDIT : I want to add, that the ability to change from modern to classic graphics was a nice touch too. Art work differences is something interesting to look at. 

7.5/10

32232378.review:
Ys 1 and 2 are essentially 2 halves of one game, and for the purpose of this review will be treated as such.

The Ys series is a collection of niche JRPG games from Falcom, famous for their difficulty and their blisteringly fast pace compared to almost every other RPg game coming out at the time (and to a degree, even today). The games are known for their heavy, intense guitar scores and serene orchestral music, as well, and these two games are the ones that began the trend for everything above.

The Ys games are notoriously polarizing - either you REALLY enjoy the gameplay, the almost bullet-hell difficulty in bosses, or you absolutely hate it and toss it in the garbage. I luckily fell into the first camp.

Ys 1 and 2 utilize the "Bump Combat System" which is a buttonless fighting style that relies on you running into enemies that are not facing you, or at odd degrees or angles (basically anything other than head-on) in order to do damage. There are ZERO i-frames in both games, for both enemies and you, so combat is swift and incredibly lethal. The only slowdown is if you have to stop to regenerate, and consumables in the second game make it so you don't even need to do that. The second game also greatly increases the power of a diagonal angle attack, making striking without taking recoil damage almost trivial after playing the first game. Ys2 also adds magic to break up the rushing bump combat formula, but for the most part you're going to be running around like a madman auto-swinigng your sword, and it is incredibly fun.

The dungeons in both games are large and pretty winding, and you do a lot of running around back and forth to collect items, but your runspeed is so high and there'sa number of fast travel options, so it never seems *too* bad. There are a few points that definitely come off like blatant padding though, especially in the second half of both games.

As a JRPG, there is some degree of grinding. If you're in the game for achievements then you won't notice any extra grinding aty all - as you'll already be killing way more monsters than necessary in order to fill up your bestiary entries. If thats not your thing, be aware that in both games there are a few hard walls that will require a bit of grinding, especially the last boss in the first half of Ys 1. Ys 1 assumes you are max level halfway through the game. Luckily levelling is quick and the grinding will be pretty minimal. Ys 2 makes things much easier, and towards the end of the game there is one particular enemy you can grind about 10-12 levels off of in 15-20 minutes. Luckily combat is realtime and so swift your grinding always has you doing something rather than "press A for turn based combat".

The music switches between soft town themes and serene temple themes, to pulse pounding electric guitar riffs in dungeons and combat zones. It's great music if that style is your thing, and is it ever my thing. Can't say enough great things about the music.

The story is interesting and intriguing, but won't knock your socks off like, say, a Witcher game, with crazy political intrigue. It's a JRPG about being a redhead anime warrior getting into adventures, and that's exactly what you get. The world setting is explained and the locations you go to across games are varied. The supporting cast exists but doesn't get a ton of screentime just by virtue of the game's style. The games are about Adol and that's made clear. There are some parts where it's not immediately clear where you need to be going - this is worse in the second game, but made a bit easier by the game giving you an item at that point that lets you 'phone a friend' for some NPC assistance on where to go next.

Strongly recommended if you can handle the game's inherent difficulty - boss battles verge on frustrating to downright unfair feeling, especially in the first game. A great update to a classic RPG. Honestly the update is what makes playing this game bearable nowadays because the combat system is very dated and there's a lot of design issues with the first Ys game that would be pretty unacceptable nowadays. It's a pretty short game, your first playthrough will be 5-6 hours most likely. The game uses "bump" combat which just consists of you running into things to deal damage. Hitting them off center will deal damage without taking any, hitting things head on will hurt you both and knock you back. It's extremely simple (primitive) but it's a 30 year old game so...what do you expect? The game has a fair amount of equipment you can find, although once you buy all of the equipment, money becomes basically worthless, and you also hit level cap about halfway into the game, so past a certain point killing monsters is nearly worthless.

All that said, if you're a fan of the later games it's still pretty cool to see how it started. The visuals have been greatly updated and look very nice, and the soundtrack is fantastic. The story is fairly cliche and a lot of things aren't explained terribly well, but again it's a 30 year old jRPG, don't go in expecting crazy things and you'll probably enjoy it. Just be prepared for some cheesy boss fights, archaic game design and lots of backtracking.

Ys II is a direct sequel to Ys I, beginning directly after the end of the first game. The combat is slightly different and it's a bit longer, but it's quite similar to the first game and ties up the story pretty well. If you enjoy the first game, you'll probably like the second at least as much if not more.

29891840.review:
[h1]What is Y's Chronicles?[/h1]

Ys I & II Chronicles+ is somewhere between The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past and Dark Souls. Being a top-down JRPG it very much looks and plays like classic Zelda, but the leveling system, combat fluidity and (brutal) bosses make it feel very much like Dark Souls. 

That said, this game is DIFFICULT and there's definitely a Dark Souls-esque learning curve for the combat (more below), trial and error with dungeons, and hair-pulling-out feeling when taking on bosses (the bosses are, for the most part, really great though). Also very much in the vein of Dark Souls, this game is very, very rewarding when you finally make your way through that maze of a dungeon, or beat the boss whose pounded your face in for the last hour.

[h1]Combat[/h1]

How can a Zelda-like game have Dark Souls like combat that's fluid and got a high learning curve? Ys uses a "Bump System" for combat; what this essentially means is your hero automatically attacks with his sword, which is initiated by "bumping" into enemies. Effective attacks are made by bumping enemies off-center, from behind, or at angles. If you hit an enemy head on or don't lock them down with effective "bump" attacks, they'll parry you and do damage when you attack. 

At first I didn't know what to think about this system, but it's AWESOME. It's fluid because you can attack quickly, move around a ton to dodge and attack, and not have to interrupt your movements with pressing a button to swing your sword (magic in Ys II however, requires a cast button for range attacks). It also provides a really high learning curve because you have to learn the best ways to attack and not take damage, and it FORCES YOU TO BE AGGRESSIVE - sorry folks, there's no standing in a corner and swinging your sword at enemies when they come at you to damage them, push them away, and repeat. 

The Bump System requires you to run at enemies, do it quickly, and always keep moving. It's HARD, but it's FUN.

[h1]Story / Progression[/h1]

Like the classic Zelda-like JRPG's (and Dark Souls), you'll find no quest-trackers here. Instead, you're forced to speak with NPC's to get hints and figure out what to do, and how to do it. Also like Dark Souls, often you'll think you found where to go only to be one-shotted by enemies and realize, "nope, this comes later." Sometimes you'll find it's hard to find out exactly how to progress, but you'll come to appreciate the thought and effort that is required to do so (or, you can use a guide). Characters are engaging, and story is simple but interesting.

[h1]Bosses[/h1]

Also very Dark Souls-like, they have tons of health, complicated attack patterns that require dodging and attacking in certain ways, and often you get to them and get your face absolutely crushed in and realize, "oh crap, I need to back up and find some better gear and grind out some more levels". I've only played the game on Hard and Nightmare mode - it's not unusual to have to try a boss 20 times before you beat him, and even then it's hard to beat them consistently. Difficulty primarily affects the complexity of boss attack patterns.

[h1]RPG Elements[/h1]

Your HP/MP are automatically upgraded as you level up, and you gain XP and Gold from defeating enemies. Most of the customization in these games comes from buying or finding upgraded armor, weapons, and other ability-altering items in dungeons. 

You will often need to customize your equipment and items for best effectiveness against certain bosses, or to make it through certain dungeons. The RPG elements are just enough to keep you engaged and actively adapting to the situation, and just simple enough that it doesn't take away from the fluidity of the gameplay (no stat-point allocation to agonize over to be found here).

[h1]Other Notes[/h1] 

Story in these games is about 10 hours for Ys I, and a bit over 15 for Ys II. Given the ease of running these games, they're also great for playing on a laptop when you're away from your gaming rig. 

While you can play with a mouse/keyboard, I recommend using a gamepad. There are also cusomization options for visuals (upgraded or classic), however they're pretty similar and don't impact the game. 

BE AWARE that "Movement" settings DO HAVE AN IMPACT ON PLAYABILITY - there is an option for 360 degree movement (like a modern joystick) and 8-Directional movement (like a classic arrow-pad. Certain bosses and dungons will be MUCH easier/more difficult based upon the movement settings you use, so don't be afraid to switch it up to increase mobility (360) or movement accuracy (8-Direction).

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

[b]Excellent game, and a definite must-buy, 9/10[/b] for any classic Zelda and Dark Souls fans. Regularly can be found on sale for under $5.

Fair warning: I'm gonna use an extended comparison to a more modern and well known game for the bulk of this review.

These are to date the only Ys games I've played and I enjoyed them. The combat system is unique even 30(!) years after their original release, with the main battle mechanic being ramming your enemies in the flanks. This gives the games a feeling of quick movement that for today's gamer can trigger an interesting response: I found myself using the same skillset, especially in regards to fight or flight, that I'd developed playing Darksouls.

The feeling of the games being a top-down, technicolored, 80's Darksouls never went away either, with common enemies that will tear you apart if you waste all your time on them and difficult boss battles. Ironically, playing this way made the bosses much harder for me (at least in Ys I) because I wound up fighting them horribly under levelled. This isn't to say either Ys is as hard as Darksouls, though if you took the bosses from Ys I and the mooks from Ys II (who were shockingly more powerful than Ys I, the bosses however...) you'd probably wind up with a game that, despite being in a very different (sub-)genre would both feel weirdly familiar and give any veteran Darksouls player a run for their money.

Finally, loved the music. Also worth noting the games are very short, first one is less than 10 hours, second is a lot longer and has a magic system that lets you do some cool stuff including hit enemies with something other than a sword.

So far I have only finished Ys I, but I will update my review as soon as I finish Ys II.

This was my first Ys game ever, so I wasn't really sure what to expect. I am not a big fan of turn-based RPGs, and was happy to see that this game is of the real-time combat variety.

The story revolves around the main character Adol, who is washed up on the shore of an island where monsters have started appearing. You start out by helping the various characters on the island, and eventually embark on an adventure to find the Books of Ys.

You kill enemies by running into them from the right angle. If you just charge straight into their face you will end up taking a lot of damage. That's pretty much how the combat works. No spells or anything, just bumping, pure and simple.

As soon as you learn how important it is to be at a high enough level and to have the best weapon and armor available equipped, the regular enemies won't be too much of an issue, even on nightmare difficulty.

The bosses, however... Some of the bosses are so easy to defeat it's stupid, while others are ridiculously and frustratingly hard. One boss I was able to beat on my first try, another it took me [i]a lot[/i] of tries to beat. Still, despite making me want to throw away my controller at times, the bosses were definitely the most fun part of the game. After finishing the main story you also unlock Time Attack Mode, which let's you try to defeat all the bosses in the game as fast as possible.

The last part of the game consists of running around talking to people, looking for items, and just figuring out where to go next. There were a couple of times where I had no idea what I was suppose to do next, however the game world is luckily not [i]too[/i] big, so you will figure it out eventually.

I thoroughly enjoyed this game, and will definitely be playing Ys II, as well as probably all the other games in the series.

Highly recommended!

Ys I and II feels weirdly dated; as in, when you play a classic game, it feels like "yeah the game is gold, but it's also old." But when I'm playing Ys I and II, I know from my mind it is an old game--it's based on Eternal versions released in 2000--but I feel like I'm playing a relatively modern indie game.
The thing that differentiates a good old school indie games from the bad ones is how modernized the game design actually is. It's not like Ys I and II doesn't have UI problems, and the dungeon design in Ys I sometimes gets downright frustrating, but the overall game design is blazing fast and mostly user-friendly. Sometimes, I feel like I'm playing a really good, modern indie ARPG with 16-bit aesthetics and pseudo-old school nostalgia, instead of a game that is actually old. And that's not a bad thing at all, because that's what makes old games like these timeless classics.

28925462.review:
After playing Ys Origins and absolutely loving that game, I decided to play Ys I and II. I'm giving both games a thumbs up, but. . . . . .

The original game was released in 1987, and it was one of the first action RPGs ever made. It shows it's age through design even if the visuals and audio were updated. I guess I'll go over a few pros and cons.

PROs:

- Fighting is fun. Even if the idea of "running into enemies to deal damage" doesn't sound appealing, it's at least an interesting idea to try out since you've probably never played a game much like it. Boss fights are awesome in design since it requires a LOT of movement, precision, and timing in order to defeat them. Be warned that there are some challenging parts in this game. Magic is also a mechanic in the game, and it really helps add variety to the combat when you get bored with running into enemies to beat them.
- World is somewhat cohesive, and the town NPCs are at least a little memorable. It's also good how the townsfolk talk about each other even when the different people are towns apart. You get to see a grandma in a village complain about her children trying to get her to move to another town, and you also get to talk to the children in the other town talking about their struggle of trying to get their mother to move to their town. This sort of thing is important because the town-exploration that is required by the player can really bog down the game if it isn't good. 
- Overall, I'd say that the story is good. It doesn't take a front-seat in this game, but it is able to find a place in a game where you are suppose to be an adventurer discovering the world, helping people, and saving the land from demons and destruction. The story is mostly established as you explore the land and talk to various NPCs. The story isn't handed to you on a sliver-platter, and I think that this is a good thing for this type of game.
- Oh yeah. the game has an RAAAAAAAAAAAD soundtrack

Cons:

- A very large number of the enemies in the game behave in the exact same way, and the way you fight them is the same a lot of the time. Just run into their side, and beat them. If the enemies each had different patterns of movement and different ways that they could damage you, the game would be much better, but at least the bosses are good. This is where the "bump-to-attack" mechanic shows its flaws. This is perhaps the worst part of the game. . . . .boring enemy design. (not in visuals but in the the way that enemies fight) 
- It also becomes very boring fighting enemies when you're lv. 20 while fighting lv. 1 enemies. Also, being able to rest on the overworld at the player's leisure just decreases the tension and fun that one could have from fighting enemies normally. This is a natural symptom to RPGs, but. . . . it still is true.
- There isn't a world map, and it is fairly easy to get lost since the screen is zoomed in, and it's hard to orient yourself to the map when the different parts of an area are indistinguishable. I suppose that the game is old-school though, and perhaps there can be some fun found in drawing your own maps with pencil and paper.
- Back-tracking to open treasure-chests that you already found but didn't have the key at the time isn't. . . . .particularly fun. It feels more like busy-work.

So, my conclusion. . . . generally good gameplay, and a good story that works well with the gameplay-focus of this game.  Oh yeah, did I also mention the AWESOME MUSIC????

7.5/10

28925319.review:
I was really interested in starting to play the Ys Series, since I grew up on SNES Jrpgs, Secret of Mana/Evermore, Final Fantasy, Lufia, Terranigma, Chrono Trigger etc etc. The graphics were really compelling and the series seems to be quite successful given how many sequels there are. So I thought I start out with the first two installments and give it a try. Well...having played through the first one on Normal up until the last boss:

Nope, not recommended.

tl;dr: grinding, backtracking, unbalanced difficulty, generic linear story with no "red line" to guide through, stupid gameplay/core mechanic. Nice combat music - overall, keep playing the classics and save it on this one.

This is a prime example of a game that aged really badly.
Horrible, downright unacceptable game design by today's standards, that was *maybe* acceptable 20 years ago.

- Core game mechanic: "bumping" into enemies is not only trivial and uninteresting, it's also random af. Hitting an enemy and getting no dmg vs getting hit, because the enemy turns around and hits you back in the last second is not only a world of difference, but there's nothing you can do from your side to "safely" execute it. You just bump into enemies sideways and "hope for the best"; no strategy or thinking/planing involved.

- Unbalanced and outright ridiculous difficulty. It starts with you being laughably underpowered and you having to GRIND at the very start of the game to even get your starter equipment to sort of start your quest. Then one or two levels down the line your enemies go from almost unbeatable to oneshots. Its like playing WOW, where you constantly either fight a mob that is 3 or more levels above you, or you are fighting lvl 1 critters. And the last 2-3 bosses are plainly insane, even on normal difficulty.

- Generic, bland story & characters & villain: Not the worst thing in the world, if the narrative was interesting at least, however...
- NO narrative whatsoever. You basically have to run around and guess what to do next. Not even at the start of the game do you have a clear objective, where to go and what to do next...it just sort of plays itself out because the number of locations is very small and eventually you would have talked to everyone.

- Grinding.....seriously..grinding in a SINGLEPLAYER game is a cardinal sin. There should be NO REASON to ever having to grind other than OPTIONAL late game stuff, like secret bosses (FF series). When you have to grind to progress in the MAIN PLOT, there's something wrong with your game balance guys..and not only that...but grinding at the START of the game? Like right off the bat grinding for your START EQUIPMENT..holy fuck.

- Backtracking... a lot. What you are dealing with here is an ordinary linear rpg, except almost all areas are open to you at once and you HAVE to have certain items or spoken to a certain person to progress. And if that person ist literally 9 dungeon floors in the back..too bad, happy backtracking or you shall not pass. 

Backtracking is just like grinding: In almost every case it's bad game design, plain and simple. And this has nothing to do with the age of the game either. There is no grinding or a lot of backtracking in any RPG that I mentioned above. There's no "this game is old" excuse. I could probably write a paper on everything what's wrong with this game, but I have to stop for now...

The music in the Chronicles version however was really awesome in some places and the graphics are indeed quite nice. But that doesn't cut it. If you are interested in retro rpgs - play any of the ones I mentioned in the beginning and save yourself the time. 

Sadly the first game in this series ruined my desire to play any sequels, and even though I know this might be unfair - the difference between good and bad Final Fantasy or Breath of Fire installments for example is, they are independent story arks. The Ys series however seems to be in continuity and if I didn't like the first game, whats the point of playing the rest?

Short review: You're in for a damn good time. Get it.

Long review: Ys I & II Chronicles+ is a remake of the two 1980's RPGs Ancient Ys Vanished: Omen and Ancient Ys Vanished: The Final Chapter. As such, they still retain the same basic gameplay and design as their original 80's counterparts, so the gameplay takes some getting used to. You don't have an attack button, you run into enemies off-center to kill them. You don't have a plethora of healing items, you have a single potion, and otherwise just stand still.

Ys I is a fun and short adventure, clocking out on an average of 5 hours, even if you're completely lost. It's a fun adventure with a simplistic story but a great, connected world with a lot of lore. However, nearly all of the boss fights are terrible, and are only difficult through arbitrary means. It's still definitely a game worth playing, though, as it leads directly into Ys II.

Ys II is a damn incredible game, and improves on the original in every way. A more expansive world, a deeper storyline, incredibly fun boss fights, absolutely beautiful music. There's not much else I can say except for the fact that Ys II is worth all the trouble you'll have in Ys I. And hey, don't like Ys I? The good news is that you can completely skip it and just go straight to the second one if you so choose (though you might be a little lost on the story at first).

Long and short of it, Ys I & II Chronicles+ is a collection of two very old but classic action RPGs. You're really in for something great here.

There is something special about the gameplay and story-telling of a lot of the games released in the late 80s and early 90s.  I cannot put my finger on exactly what it is, but VERY few games, if any, nail that exact formula today (The most recent I can think of that I played being the first Golden Sun). Despite the limited graphics and simple gameplay, there is just something that makes the stories and characters seem to come to life and the world just call out for every house, forest, cave and secret to be explored. I would be tempted to chock it all up to nostalgia, except that I had never played a single Ys game until recently here on steam. Thus far, I have finished Ys I and cannot wait to move on to II. This game, originally released in the late 80s and updated with beautiful 32-bit style gameplay graphics and hand drawn anime style cut-scenes and character profiles, nails that formula. It's been given a nice new paint job and some optional updated musical scores, but even with all these things the old heart and soul of this classic game still shines through, perhaps all the brighter, and even to a new comer like myself. I am reminded of the first time I played The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past (so perhaps there is some form of nostalgia at play here after all).

I was VERY skeptical of the strange "bump combat" system at first.  I still wouldn't say it's ideal. I'm glad it did not become a standard in games, but after spending some time with it, and leveling up a little, it actually is nowhere near as bad as it seems at first and becomes quite enjoyable.

The graphics, artwork (of which you can select 2 versions), and music (of which you can select a few versions) are absolutely beautiful.  The characters and dialogue are interesting, fun, and memorable.  The story is engaging. The puzzles are fun.  The combat can range between frustrating and fun, but isn't bad once you get used to it.

Overall I would recommend this game to just about anyone, but especially to those looking for that missing charm that games once had.

27575242.review:
The latest iteration of the games (yes, games) that kicked off one of the greatest and longest-running action-RPG series of all-time, Ys I & II Chronicles+ enhances the '80s classics for a new age. XSEED went above and beyond the call of duty with this release: they took the Ys I & II Complete release from 2001 and updated it with the content from the later Chronicles release on the PSP circa 2009.

Ys I & II Chronicles+ recounts the first two adventures of Adol Christin, better known as "Adol the Red" in the continent of Esteria and the mysterious lost continent of Ys. If you've played an earlier iteration of these games (the most popular version was the TurboGrafx-16 release), you're probably familiar with the storyline, though there have been a few changes here and there -- including a brand new area at the beginning of Ys I.

The gameplay is a far more refined version of the classic "run-and-bump" gameplay associated with the series. Adol attacks his enemies by ramming into his enemies off-center, while getting rammed or ramming into them on-center deals damage to Adol instead. This is expanded on in Ys II with additional magic attacks, such as the ability to shoot fireballs, warp and Adol can even disguise himself as a creature, in order to talk to monsters.

The graphics aren't breathtaking by any means, but they're the best-looking iteration of these classic games out there. There are some nice full-motion video cutscenes as well, though some may argue they lack the "charm" of those present in the TG-16 version. Music is amazing as always: some have even argued that the new rearrangements made for Chronicles rival those of Ryo Yonemitsu. Additional unused tracks have been reimplemented into the game, to add more diversity to the soundtrack compared to earlier versions.  As a bonus, the game also includes the option to use both the classic PC-88 soundtrack (the original versions of Ys I & II), as well as the remixed music from Complete.

If the game has any major flaws, I'd have to say it's the fact that both Ys I & II are considered separate games -- both in the Steam library, as well as in general. That is to say, you don't actually need to complete Ys I in order to play Ys II, unlike the TG-16 version which wove both games into a seamless experience. By extension, this means that any experience gained in Ys I doesn't carry over to Ys II. Therefore, Ys I retains the somewhat uneven levelling and low level cap (you can only reach Lv. 10) from earlier iterations.

If you've never played a single Ys game before, this would be the one to start with. While the "run-and-bump" battle system was replaced with a more traditional hack-and-slash mechanic in the other games currently available on Steam, it's still an interesting system that deserves to be enjoyed by all. If you've played Ys I & II before, you can probably skip out on this one -- though I'd consider this version to be the definitive version.

Ys I: Ein absoluter Klassiker und obendrein der Startschuss für eine tolle Action-RPG-Serie!

Es ist schon erstaunlich wie gut sich dieses Spiel gehalten hat. Sicherlich handelt es sich um ein Remake, jedoch basiert das Grundgerüst immer noch auf dem originalem Ys, welches Anno 1987 veröffentlicht wurde. Der schnelle Spielablauf sucht seinesgleichen und es wird eine hervorragende Balance zwischen Simplizität und Anspruch geboten. Man kann sich direkt ins Spiel stürzen ohne irgendwelche Anleitungen zu wälzen, aber wer Ys durchspielen möchte, sollte schon ein gewisses Maß an Geschicklichkeit und Verstand mitbringen. Kurz gesagt: Ein echter Retro-Klassiker und absoluter Pflichttitel für jeden Retro-Spieler und Freunde des Action-Rollenspiels!


Pro und Kontra:

Pro:
- sehr flotter Spielablauf
- simples und geniales „Anrempel“-Kampfsystem
- wunderschöne Sprite-Grafiken im 16-bit-Stil
- cooler J-Rock-Soundtrack mit Ohrwurm-Garantie
- erfordert Eigeninitiative bei der Erforschung der Spielwelt und Lösung der Item-Rätsel
- zahlreiche, sympathische Nebencharaktere
- flüssige und konfigurierbare Tastatur- und Controller-Steuerung

Neutral:
- ca. 5-7 Stunden Spielzeit
- bietet nur eine kleine, aber dafür offene Spielwelt
- eine klassische Handlung ohne echte Besonderheiten

Kontra:
- könnte für manchen zu „Retro“ sein, weil man eben selber gucken muss wo man bleibt
- das „Anrempel“-Kampfsystem dürfte wohl auch nicht jedem gefallen
- einige Bosskämpfe wirken unfair, da man eingesteckten Schaden oftmals nicht verhindern kann und es noch nicht mal erlaubt ist Hilfsmittel wie Heiltränke in einem Bosskampf einzusetzen


================================================


Ys II: Konsequente Fortsetzung eines Klassikers

Wer den ersten Teil mochte, wird auch den Zweiten mögen. Die Kernspielelemente, welche den Vorgänger so gut gemacht haben, wurden beibehalten und durch neue Dinge ergänzt. So bekommt Adol ein paar Zaubersprüche zur Verfügung gestellt und der Umfang des Spiels wurde mal eben verdoppelt. Abseits einiger kleinerer Änderungen, die ohnehin in den Bereich des persönlichen Geschmacks fallen, kann eigentlich nur der Soundtrack als echter Kritikpunkt genannt werden, und das auch nur, weil er nicht an die Ohrwurm-Brillanz des vorherigen Spiels heranreicht. Dies ist jedoch Meckern auf sehr hohem Niveau, denn auch Ys II ist ein klasse Action-Rollenspiel, welches Fans von Retro-Games und Action-Rollenspielen sehr viel Freude bereiten wird.

Ys I & II Chronicles + ist einfach ein hervorragendes Remake und eine tolle Compilation für all jene, die schon immer mal die Anfänge dieser schönen Action-RPG-Saga miterleben wollten. Der Preis von 11,99 € ist obendrein sehr fair gehalten. Wer hier nicht zuschlägt ist selber schuld.


Pro und Kontra:

Pro:
- die Vorzüge von Ys I gelten auch für die Fortsetzung
- das Spielprinzip wurde um Zaubersprüche erweitert
- die Spieldauer wurde auf ca. 10-14 Stunden angehoben
- weitere Detailverbesserungen (Geschenke-System, höherer Level-Cap, ...)

Neutral:
- Ys II bietet keine Open World wie der Vorgänger, sondern ist linear aufgebaut
- eine klassische Handlung ohne echte Besonderheiten
- der Schwierigkeitsgrad wurde abgewandelt, Kämpfe sind nun leichter, aber die Adventure-Elemente dafür anspruchsvoller

Kontra:
- könnte für manchen zu „Retro“ sein, weil man eben selber gucken muss wo man bleibt
- das „Anrempel“-Kampfsystem dürfte wohl auch nicht jedem gefallen
- der neue Soundtrack kommt nicht an den des Vorgängers heran

There's so much good to say about Ys I and II Chronicles. First of all, it's two games in one, and both games are of stellar quality. Excellent sprite and artwork, an absolutely stunning soundtrack, endearing characters, especially that of the main character, Adol, and a surprisingly efficient and fast-paced combat system.

When a game features combat but 'not' an attack button, that would give any gamer pause. On paper, that would seem clunky at best and unintuitive at worst. However, the "bump system" implimented renders the need for an attack button practically obsolete, to the point where I actually question the very existence of what is otherwise an unquestionably essential feature in an action game. 

What the bump system does is automatically calculate your attack, your defence, and your receiving of damage upon colliding with any enemy, and the chances of how that collision will play out change depending on which angle you bump into the enemy. If you hit them from behind or from an angle, typically your mow through them like a lawn mower. If you get bumped into yourself, you'll take damage, and if you collide face first with an enemy, you and the enemy will either take damage or block, and both will be knocked away. 

Once you master the bump system, you'll literally mow down enemies at a much faster pace than you would a Zelda title, which this game resembles aesthetically. In fact, the Ys series is, in many ways, the Sonic to Zelda's Mario. Where Zelda is a more balanced and safe experience, where you can always expect a blend of puzzles and combat, Ys games, typically, are faster, flashier, and more experimental than any Zelda title. While this has had mixed to poor resulte for Sonic, I've yet to play an Ys game I didn't like.

If you're looking to get into the Ys series, this is definitely the game(s) to do it with.

The Ys series are ARPGs with very minimal progression elements.  You wont be sifting through tons of loot, and you wont be spending stats or making builds.  You will instead be engaging in lots and lots of combat, which is the games biggest flaw. The fights in this game are very rudimentary, and they happen to the point of ad nasuem.  Sadly the progression elements render any kind of strategy null, as you'll either be far beyond any enemy in power, or unable to take two hits from them.  

I may be ragging on the game a bit here, but Ys 1 & 2 are actually good games. The music is pretty decent, the visuals, especially the updated ones, are pleasant and harken back to high fantasy from the 80s/90s.  The world and environment really hammer the fantasy atmosphere home.

The story and characters arent all that intriguing, but that is owning, again, to the games dated nature.  The narrative here is nothing new, but it isnt annoying.  Faint praise, I know

Honestly, I do recommend this game, but cautiously.  If you enjoyed a lot of old high fantasy material, or you played some of the more recent games, give the game a go.  It may surprise you. If you instead play many RPGs or ARPGs of today's modern game designs you may find the barebones systems and story a bit too lackluster to get into.

A package of both the original Ys games in one remastered edition. It actually contains both the Chronicles (2001) and Complete (2009) editions, including updated visuals and soundtracks.

The Ys games are known for not dilly-dallying around and is a fast paced action game with light RPG elements. You run around bumping into enemies, leveling up, earning gold and buying better equipment.

The first game is not as good as the sequel, but is a solid introduction to the series nontheless. The story is that some ancient evil power thing is causing monsters to roam havoc in Ys and Esteria. One day Adol falls out of the sky and lands in this very land, becoming the protagonist and saviour of the land.

Both games features a bump system where you basically walk into enemies to take them out. The first game requires you to hit enemies off center to take them out without taking damage and this is further expanded upon in the sequel where you also can bump successfully diagonally. This makes the battles way easier, ensuring you're staying alive longer.

While the first Ys I is a bit easing on the mechanics, it does feature harder bosses than the sequel. It's around 6-7 hours in length, while Ys II Vanished the Final Chapter is around double the length, at around 12-14 hours. It is by far the superior of the two, featuring a much bigger world and alot more items to procure.

Speaking of items, both games requires you to do A-LOT of backtracking and won't hold your hand in telling you where all of them are. These are the type of games that enforces you to explore, run around and figuring it all out for yourself. If you're not using a guide, expect to get stuck some times as it is not always clear what to do next. Both games also features some highly missable (and some VERY doubious) achievements as well, like shoving a girl and a boy up in a corner to "measure" them. The game does feature plenty of humor too, though and like its tongue-in-cheek moments from time to time.

For the price you're getting a decent pack of entertainment here. Even better if you get it on sale (which happens pretty often). The story may not be very inspiring, but the soundtrack is stellar. Falcom is known for always composing great soundtrack for their games and this is no exception.

Ys I: 5.5/10
Ys II Vanished The Final Chapter: 9/10

24767831.review:
Ys I & II Chronicles is a much improved remake of the 1987/1988 Falcom games for the NEC PC88 and PC98 computers.  The two games are essentially one, with II being a direct sequel to I.  Unlike most Ys games, where the events are loosely connected and don't need to be played in any particular order, Ys I and II should be played together, in order.  I also personally recommend these games as an introduction to the series, as they introduce some of the main recurring characters of the series.  Both games come with 3 soundtracks - the original PC88 version, the Ys I & II Complete version, and the Ys I & II Chronicles version.  While I personally have a love for the FM synth of the original (PC98 VGM is amazing), all 3 soundtracks are fantastic and there's really no "best" version.  Having multiple choices was a very nice touch from Falcom.  With introductions out of the way though, let's get into the individual games.

- Ys I - 
Ys I is a mediocre game with an odd charm.  While not nearly as good as its sequel, it's still a nice game.  Much of the time there's little clue where to go or what to do, but something about freely roaming the world talking to NPCs to find a clue as to what to do next reminds me of a simpler time and just has a nice feeling to it.  Also, unlike many RPGs, every NPC has a name and a small sense of uniqueness that makes the interactions with them more enjoyable.  This is honestly one of my favorite parts of this game, and of Falcom games in general.

The combat is pretty simplistic in Ys - bumping into enemies will damage them, but hitting them head-on will hurt you a lot as well, so you must hit them from off-center to avoid taking damage.  It's a nice system, and I like it, but it wasn't executed as well as it could have been in this game.  You reach the maximum level about halfway through the game, which makes fighting enemies feel unrewarding for the remainder.  The boss design also a bit poor, which is sad.  They're functional and not really "bad", but they're still some of the poorer-quality bosses of the series.  That said, while the gameplay is a touch mediocre, the characters, story, and music still work well to make the game feel nice despite its flaws.

- Ys II -

Ys II is the direct sequel to Ys I, taking place immediately after the events of its prequel.  This game takes everything that made Ys I good, and makes it better.  Then it takes everything that was bad about Ys I, and makes it good.  The game's progression feels so much smoother and more straight-forward than the first, and the combat system has been improved by adding magic to the mix.  Early in the game, Adol will gain access to his first spell, a chargable fireball spell, giving more choice in combat alongside the traditional bump-combat.  The boss design has also stepped up from mediocre to magnificent.  Ys II's bosses are very much up to par with the later installments of the series, and are by far the best of the 2d games.  Most bosses can only be damaged by the fireballs, giving them a shoot-em-up type feel, where you must dodge their attacks while shooting them with your charged up fireballs.  Also, unlike the first game, Adol will level up continually throughout the entire game, and experience gains are now adjusted relative to the difference in levels from enemies, helping to keep the player from being over or under leveled.  There's also lots of small touches to the game that add so much to it, such as being able to give gifts to NPCs for additional dialogues or other small secrets.  Ys II is a fantastic game and one of the best in the series, definitely standing up well alongside its 3d successors.  I highly recommend it.
